DataElement.preferredName: Diagnostic Imaging Abdominal Pelvis Computed Tomography Or Magnetic Resonance Imaging Negation Metastasis Performed Most Recent Date
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The most recent date related to an abdominal/pelvis computed tomography or magnetic resonance imaging that has no metastasis.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Diagnostic Imaging Abdominal Pelvis Computed Tomography Or Magnetic Resonance Imaging Negation Metastasis Performed
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation._Of, or related to, the abdomen._The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans._A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis._An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise._Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders._An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction._The spread or migration of cancer cells from one part of the body (the organ in which it first appeared) to another. The secondary tumor contains cells that are like those in the original (primary) tumor._Executed and carried through to completion.

Concepts.definition: Of, or related to, the abdomen.
The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans.
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.

Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.
An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.

The spread or migration of cancer cells from one part of the body (the organ in which it first appeared) to another. The secondary tumor contains cells that are like those in the original (primary) tumor.
Executed and carried through to completion.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the most recent date of an event, assessment, or treatment.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Nearest to the present time.:a particular day specified as the time something has, or will, happen.

Concepts.definition: The particular day, month and year an event has happened or will happen.

ReferenceDocuments.description: Most recent abdominal/pelvis CT or MRI documenting no evidence of metastasis
